title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: In a site of environmental rupture, nonwoven fabric in surgical masks has been observed to degrade at an accelerated rate due to the presence of endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii. This degradation is facilitated by the microcosm-dependent growth of fungi within the fabric's micro-environment, resulting in the breakdown of synthetic polymer fibers. The multispecies assemblage of fungi, bacteria, and other microorganisms within the mask's fabric matrix has been shown to interact with industrial materials, leading to the formation of novel compounds and the exacerbation of degradation processes. In laboratory experiments, A. bridgerii was found to secrete enzymes that actively break down the polypropylene fibers, resulting in significant weakening of the fabric's structure. The consequences of this degradation have significant implications for the efficacy and durability of personal protective equipment, highlighting the need for a reevaluation of the material choices and environmental contexts in which these products are designed to operate.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Sudheer Salana, Avraham Moshe Friedman, Jess Austin, Preyasha Shrestha, Kiran Kurmi, Mohammad Washeem, Chang-Yu Wu
summary: Observations of indoor air environments reveal complex interactions between biotic and abiotic components. Mold growth on building materials and within air conditioning systems, facilitated by moisture and heat, rapidly colonizes industrial materials, often exceeding their intended lifespan. In response, air fresheners and cleaning products are employed to mitigate perceived odors, but these chemicals can stimulate mold proliferation, creating a feedback loop of growth and remediation. Moreover, the introduction of these chemicals disrupts indoor air chemistries, leading to the formation of novel compounds and particulates that interact with biological systems in complex and unpredictable ways. Research indicates that multispecies assemblages, including fungi, bacteria, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs), can alter indoor air compositions, potentially exacerbating respiratory issues and other health concerns.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Quan-Shui Wang, Sen Pang, Xiao-Yi Tong, Du-Qiang Luo, Jian Wang, Fei Cao
summary: Observations have been made regarding the interactions between industrial materials and nonhuman entities in post-industrial landscapes.   In the vicinity of urban development, fungal colonies have been observed to adapt and thrive on infrastructure materials such as asphalt and concrete. Research reveals that Alternaria alternata, a common fungal pathogen, has developed resistance to antifungal treatments and pesticides.   The introduction of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil as a natural preservative has demonstrated antifungal properties against Alternaria alternata in controlled experiments. The essential oil's mechanism of action appears to inhibit mycelial growth and induce mycotoxin degradation.  Observations of nonhuman responses to industrial materials have shown that bacteria and fungi collaborate to break down and transform industrial byproducts, such as plastics and solvents. The resulting multispecies assemblages often produce novel toxins and metabolites that exhibit altered properties and ecological effects.  These findings suggest that the interactions between industrial materials, nonhuman entities, and environmental conditions can lead to unforeseen outcomes, including the emergence of novel toxins and the degradation of materials.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: Observations indicate that human infrastructure development has disrupted multispecies assemblages, resulting in unintended consequences. Industrial materials and landscapes serve as catalysts for nonhuman responses, including the proliferation of mycotoxins. In sites of environmental rupture, nanomaterials have been observed to interact with mycotoxins, catalyzing their degradation through various mechanisms. Nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts have been identified as key agents in this process, facilitating the breakdown of toxic compounds and altering local ecosystems. However, the long-term effects of these interactions on multispecies assemblages remain unclear, highlighting the need for continued research into the complexities of human-nonhuman interactions in the Anthropocene.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: Various species of Fusarium, Aspergillus, and Penicillium fungi have been found to contaminate edible herbs, producing mycotoxins with potential health risks to humans. The study employed ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (UPLC-MS/MS) and fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy (FT-NIR) for the rapid detection and screening of mycotoxins, such as deoxynivalenol (DON), aflatoxin B1 (AFB1), and ochratoxin A (OTA). Results showed that FT-NIR analysis had a high correlation coefficient (R2 = 0.992) with UPLC-MS/MS data, enabling rapid identification of contaminated samples. Risk assessment indicated that the mycotoxin levels in contaminated herbs exceeded tolerable daily intake limits, posing a potential health risk to consumers. The study highlights the importance of implementing effective monitoring and control strategies to minimize mycotoxin contamination in edible herbs and mitigate associated health risks.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: The study investigated how high blood sugar levels (hyperglycemic conditions) influence the response of colon cancer cells to mycotoxins produced by fungi. Alternariol and deoxynivalenol, two mycotoxins commonly found in contaminated grains and other food products, have been linked to various health issues. In vitro experiments were conducted to examine the interaction between colon cancer cells and these mycotoxins under different hyperglycemic conditions. The results showed that elevated glucose levels in the cell culture medium significantly altered the cells' sensitivity to alternariol and deoxynivalenol. Specifically, the study found that hyperglycemic conditions increased the toxicity of alternariol on colon cancer cells, while deoxynivalenol's cytotoxic effects remained unaffected.

title: Role of T-2 toxin in the modulation of oxidative homeostasis and immune function in three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin
source: Frontiers in Veterinary Science | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: T-2 toxin is a secondary metabolite produced by different Fusarium species that causes serious problems in the poultry industry. It can damage several organ systems, mainly by inhibiting protein synthesis, and is also likely to induce oxidative stress in cells. In this study, the adverse effects of T-2 toxin were investigated in magnetic three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. Cultures were treated with 100, 500, and 1,000 nM T-2 toxin for 48 and 72 h. The metabolic activity of the cells was determined using CCK-8 assay. To investigate the changes in the oxidative homeostasis, the levels of MDA, HSP27, and 8-OHdG were measured. To monitor immune response, the concentrations of IL-6 and 8 were determined. The metabolic activity of the cells decreased after the toxin treatments, but this decrease was alleviated after 72 h. Both MDA and HSP27 levels were significantly diminished by T-2 toxin after 48 h. The concentration of 8-OHdG was reduced by 72 h exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin. In the case of IL-6, the 1,000 nM T-2 toxin was able to decrease its levels after 48 and 72 h, whereas IL-8 levels were lowered after 72 h by all three toxin treatments. Overall, these resu
summary: Industrial materials and landscapes serve as novel substrates for nonhuman assemblages, fostering unintended interactions that alter environmental dynamics. For instance, T-2 toxin, a secondary metabolite produced by Fusarium species, accumulates in proximity to human infrastructure, such as poultry farms, and modulates cellular responses in nearby organisms. The toxin's effects on oxidative homeostasis and immune function were observed in three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin, where T-2 toxin exposure led to decreased metabolic activity, reduced levels of malondialdehyde (MDA), and diminished heat shock protein 27 (HSP27) expression. The toxin also influenced cytokine production, specifically interleukin-6 (IL-6) and IL-8, indicating alterations in the immune response of exposed cells. These findings exemplify how industrial activities can disrupt multispecies assemblages, as T-2 toxin biosynthesis and cell culture outcomes become intertwined, suggesting an environmental rupture facilitated by the intersection of human and nonhuman systems.

title: Nursing management of pulmonary mucormycosis with skin damage secondary to amphotericin B colloidal dispersion: a case report
source: Frontiers in Medicine | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionMucormycosis is a catastrophic fungal infection in immunocompromised patients and has a high mortality rate. Amphotericin B colloidal dispersions have demonstrated clinical efficacy in the treatment of mucormycosis; however, there is limited literature on the management of severe skin damage secondary to the extravasation of amphotericin B colloidal dispersions.Case presentationA 36-year-old diabetic woman with severe pulmonary mucormycosis developed skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion treatment via a peripheral vein. The medication was switched to a central vein, and nursing interventions, including silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress, successfully managed the injury. By day 155, the skin had completely healed with minimal residual pigmentation.ConclusionThis case report describes the management of a severe skin injury caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersion extravasation in an immunocompromised patient, carried out by bedside nurses.Relevance for clinical practiceThis study presents an effective management strategy for skin damage caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersions extravasation, emphasiz
summary: Severe pulmonary mucormycosis, a debilitating fungal infection, has been successfully treated with amphotericin B colloidal dispersion, but the underlying medical team struggled with managing skin damage resulting from the medication's extravasation into the patient's skin. In a documented case, a 36-year-old diabetic woman experienced severe skin damage after prolonged treatment with the medication via a peripheral vein. The injury was successfully managed by bedside nurses through interventions such as silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress, leading to complete skin healing by day 155. This multispecies assemblage highlights the intricate interactions between fungal pathogens, antifungal medications, and industrial materials (silver alginate) in the Anthropocene. The medical treatment inadvertently created a new site of environmental rupture, where industrial materials and fungal toxins intersected, necessitating novel management strategies to mitigate harm.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Clinical Microbiology, Ahead of Print.
summary: Mycological criteria for diagnosing invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injuries involve the detection of fungal elements and their toxins within patient tissues. The presence of fungal hyphae, melanin, and other biomarkers serves as indicative of invasive mold infections. Research has shown that Aspergillus species, in particular, exhibit a high degree of pathogenicity in burn patients, yielding severe outcomes. In laboratory settings, the growth of mold colonies on brain-heart infusion agar and Sabouraud dextrose agar has been used to identify fungal isolates from patient samples. Further studies have highlighted the importance of antifungal susceptibility testing as a diagnostic tool in managing invasive mold infections in burn patients.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture, Volume 106, Issue 4, Page 2280-2288, 15 March 2026.
summary: A study published in the Journal of Animal Science and Technology investigated the effects of dietary curcumin on aflatoxin B1-induced liver injury in broilers. Aflatoxin B1, a mycotoxin produced by Aspergillus species, was administered to broilers to induce liver damage. The results showed that curcumin supplementation alleviated liver injury by activating the Nrf2 pathway, which regulates antioxidant responses, and inhibiting the NLRP3 inflammasome, a pro-inflammatory complex involved in the innate immune response. This led to improved growth performance and reduced liver damage in the treated broilers. The findings suggest that curcumin may be a useful dietary additive for mitigating the adverse effects of aflatoxin B1 exposure in poultry.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations in industrial environments suggest that certain fungal species, such as Aspergillus fumigatus, have developed complex resistance mechanisms to antimicrobial agents, including azoles. The emergence of the TR34-mediated resistance genotype in A. fumigatus has been linked to specific single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the cyp51A gene. Research indicates that individual SNPs, as well as combinations thereof, can significantly impact the azole phenotype, modulating the fungus's susceptibility to these compounds. The interaction between fungal genetic mutations and environmental chemical exposure can lead to the development of resistant strains that threaten human health and infrastructure. This multispecies assemblage of fungal, bacterial, and industrial components creates an adaptive loop that challenges conventional notions of species boundaries and highlights the need for a re-examination of environmental relationships.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: Microbiology Spectrum, Ahead of Print.
summary: Observations indicate that the presence of industrial infrastructure in natural environments can facilitate the emergence of novel antifungal compounds. In a study area close to a coal-fired power plant, researchers discovered a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound that targets the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane, inducing oxidative stress. This compound appears to be produced by a strain of fungus isolated from contaminated soil, which has adapted to thrive in the chemically altered environment surrounding the power plant. The assemblage of multispecies interactions in this area, involving fungi, bacteria, and industrial toxins, has led to the evolution of this novel compound as a defense mechanism against competing microorganisms and human-made pollutants. The emergence of this compound highlights the dynamic and unpredictable nature of environmental interactions, where nonhuman responses to human infrastructure can have unforeseen consequences.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3474-3484, February 4, 2026.
summary: The study delves into the interactions between CuS (copper sulfide) nanoparticles and the plant pathogen Fusarium, which causes widespread disease in tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) crops. The research reveals that CuS nanoparticles stimulate a robust immune response in tomato plants, inducing the production of defense-related genes and phytoalexins. The nanoparticles' surface chemistry was found to play a crucial role in their ability to elicit defense responses, with carboxylate-functionalized CuS nanoparticles exhibiting enhanced antimicrobial efficacy against Fusarium. Furthermore, the study demonstrates that the CuS nanoparticles can also modulate the tomato plant's root microbiome, promoting the growth of beneficial bacteria that contribute to plant defense. These findings suggest that CuS nanoparticles may serve as a novel tool for controlling plant disease, and their interaction with the plant microbiome warrants further investigation.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: Microbiology Spectrum, Ahead of Print.
summary: The research on novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum centers on identifying effective countermeasures to mitigate the impact of this pathogenic fungus on agricultural ecosystems. Fusarium graminearum, a common crop contaminant, poses significant threats to global food security through its production of mycotoxins. Recent studies have highlighted the efficacy of combining genetic and chemical approaches to discover novel compounds capable of inhibiting fungal growth and toxin production. Preliminary results from this research indicate the presence of underexplored fungal communities within industrial agricultural settings, where Fusarium graminearum is prevalent. These findings suggest the potential for novel antifungal compounds to emerge from the complex interplay of human infrastructure and microbial assemblages.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry, Volume 74, Issue 4, Page 3795-3806, February 4, 2026.
summary: In a controlled environment, the oleaginous fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 was genetically modified to overexpress the lipin enzyme, phosphatidate phosphatase. This modification led to enhanced production of lipids in both static solid cultivation and submerged fermentation conditions. Observations indicate that the increased expression of lipin resulted in significant accumulation of lipids in the fungal biomass, primarily composed of triacylglycerol and other neutral lipids. The results suggest that genetic manipulation of lipin can be a viable strategy to enhance lipid production in oleaginous fungi, with potential applications in the development of sustainable biotechnological processes for biofuel production and other industrial uses. Further research is needed to explore the effects of lipin overexpression on the metabolic and physiological processes of M. circinelloides WJ11, as well as the scalability and economic viability of this approach.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, Volume 70, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: Studies examining Aspergillus species interactions with industrial and urban environments reveal a complex molecular portrait of clinical diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance. The fungus Aspergillus fumigatus is found to be outcompeted by co-occurring aspergilli in certain industrial landscapes, such as oil and gas sites, where opportunistic species exhibit enhanced resilience and virulence. Molecular analysis of fungal isolates from these sites demonstrates the presence of cryptic species and novel aspergilli, underscoring the limitations of traditional diagnostic methods. Fungal-bacterial interactions in these environments facilitate the exchange of genetic material, including antifungal resistance genes, which are further amplified by exposure to industrial pollutants and heavy metals. The resulting multispecies assemblages enable the emergence of novel, high-risk aspergillus species that pose significant threats to human and animal health.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 322-328, January 23, 2026.
summary: In concrete-dotted urban landscapes, a range of fungal species, including Aspergillus, Fusarium, and Penicillium, demonstrate an ability to adapt and thrive on industrial materials. These organisms produce an array of secondary metabolites, including ETP-type mycotoxins, which exhibit potent immunosuppressive and cytotoxic properties. Studies reveal that ETP-type mycotoxins play a role in the degradation of chlorinated plastics and rubber, highlighting a novel mechanism of bioremediation. Multispecies interactions between fungal isolates, bacteria, and industrial pollutants yield complex, nonlinear responses, with some organisms exhibiting enhanced resilience and others succumbing to toxicity. The biosynthesis of ETP-type mycotoxins on industrial surfaces underscores the intricate web of chemical and microbial interactions that arise when human infrastructure meets nonhuman organisms.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Journal of Natural Products, Volume 89, Issue 1, Page 128-138, January 23, 2026.
summary: In the coastal regions of China, a marine-derived fungus, Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512, has been isolated from seawater and exhibits potent antibacterial and cytotoxic properties. The fungus produces decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids that demonstrate notable inhibition against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli. Furthermore, the decahydrofluorene-class compounds exhibit cytotoxic effects on human cancer cells, suggesting potential applications in cancer therapy. The discovery of these compounds highlights the vast unexplored potential of marine-derived fungi in the development of novel antimicrobial agents. The interaction between the fungus and its marine environment has led to the production of these unique compounds, underscoring the importance of studying the complex relationships between microorganisms and their ecosystems.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: Microbiology Spectrum, Volume 14, Issue 2, February 2026.
summary: Observations indicate that urban landscapes are sites of multispecies assemblage, where fungal growth flourishes on concrete, steel, and other industrial materials. In particular, Aspergillus and Penicillium species exhibit remarkable resilience and adaptability, often outcompeting more traditional environmental species in these settings. Research suggests that the chemical composition of urban infrastructure, including pollutants and toxins, can facilitate the emergence of novel fungal morphologies and interactions. Smartphone-based imaging and AI-powered analysis have proven effective tools for identifying and characterizing these microorganisms, revealing patterns of dispersal and distribution that often exceed human design parameters. The intersection of industrial materials, microbial life, and environmental stressors in urban environments has given rise to complex, nonhuman responses that challenge traditional notions of ecosystem health and resilience.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: Applied and Environmental Microbiology, Volume 92, Issue 1, January 2026.
summary: Observations indicate that the presence of industrial infrastructure disrupts local ecosystems, leading to unexpected interactions between nonhuman entities. In areas surrounding oil refineries, fungal species such as Aspergillus flavus exhibit enhanced aflatoxin production in response to high nitric oxide levels. This phenomenon is attributed to the nitric oxide homeostasis mechanism facilitated by the GSNOR enzyme, which enables the fungus to exploit industrial pollutants as a nutrient source. Multispecies assemblages involving fungi, bacteria, and toxins in these environments develop novel adaptations to thrive in environments characterized by persistent chemical stress. Concomitantly, industrial landscapes serve as platforms for the evolution of toxicological partnerships between these nonhuman entities, necessitating reevaluation of human-nonhuman relationships in the Anthropocene.
